author: gcolvin
content: <@789406585888833558>o, I've been making those arguments for years, and am not going down that rabbit hole.  As the last "founder" left I can say that we valued pulling the community together, and I fear this proposal is the start of a process of pulling it apart.  I am not fundamentally opposed to keeping ERCs and EIPs in separate "filing cabinets", but before we do that I want to know -- in some detail -- what changes that split enables and how they support maintaining a unified community of Ethereum developers.  If our philosophy has shifted so much that such a community is not a core value then I don't want to participate.

author: _shemnon
content:
I’m tempted to go line by line, but I’ll start by quoting kdenhartog from the EIP-1 pain relief PR https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/7230#issuecomment-1633342493

> The biggest problem today is that we've created a governance pattern of vetocracy, where if an editor opposes a change within the EIP-1 process a single veto can nix forward progress.

Your appeal to authority (As the last “founder”) is an appeal to centralization, the antithesis of Ethereum’s core values.  Acceding to the requests of the community is more inline with decentralization.  The desire to compel people into one single community is another feature of centralization.

The process isn’t pulling apart, it has been pulling apart for years and the split is a late stage attempt to keep the EIP process before it completely unravels.  Ask your self: where are the Consensus Layer specifications?  Where are the CL change proposals?  Where is the Dencun meta-EIP?  They have all already left because the process doesn’t serve them.

author: _shemnon
content:
1. Finite set of viable prototype (core, existing clients) vs. stand alone PoCs (ERC)
2. multiple levels of review: viability then detail focused (core, EIP6780) vs. last call "please read me" reviews (ERC)
3. Default WG (core) vs having to assemble a WG (ERC)

author: gcolvin
content: Those are differences, yes.

author: _shemnon
content: Lets's add #4 - the draft/EFI/CFI/testnet/mainnet workflow (core) vs. the current flow (ERC).  If wallets disagree on an RPC it won't break the network.  If core disagrees on a failure case in a precompile and it ships, the whole network stops.
